More Good News: No Articles! Articles like 'the' and 'a' appear everywhere. In fact, they are some of the most common words in the English language. But do they really do anything? Try saying a few sentences without the articles. It might sound funny, but you'll find that it doesn't really change the meaning. In Chinese, there are no articles. For example, whether you want to say 'l am the cat' or 'I am a cat,' you would use 'wõ shì mão', which directly translates as 'I am cat. This may seem wishy-washy-sometimes it really does matter whether you are the cat or cat, but you can almost always tell from context alone which is the case. The Perfect Translation: You might think some of our translations are a bit clumsy or don't exactly sound like something a native speaker would say. In fact, we try to style the translations (within bounds, of course) so that they are most helpful when learning Chinese, which doesn't always correspond to the most elegant phrasing. For example, ' 我 要喝 一 碗汤 ( wǒ yào hē yī wăn täng)' could translate to 'I want to eat soup,' but given the English alone you might not be able to form the Chinese sentence. 'I want to drink a bowl of soup' may be a bit of an awkward sentence, but it's much more helpful when trying to come up with the Chinese translation. This often comes up with past and future tense, as well. 'On Wednesday I go to the hospital' might seem odd because if Wednesday is in the future, you would probably say 'I will go' rather than 'I go.' But since this is not reflected in the Chinese translation ' 星期三 我 去 医院 ( xingqisan wǒ qù yīyuàn ) ' , we omit the 'will' to make it easier to understand the Chinese sentence structure. How's it hangin? How do Chinese people greet each other? It's actually not as simple as you might think. The obvious answers is ' nihǎo ' , but this is a bit formal , almost always used when you are first meeting someone. An older neighbor might greet you in the morning with ' 你 吃 了 吗 ( ni chi le ma)”?, which literally means 'Have you eaten?' For students and young adults, there's no real equivalent for 'what's up?' Chinese people almost never ask '你 好吗 ( ni hao ma ) ? ' . Instead , friends often greet each other with a simple (hēi)' (a transliteration of 'hey') followed by the person 's name , as in John ! ' Also common are ' 早上 好 ( zǎoshàng hao, good morning) ' and ' 晚上 好 ( wǎnshàng hao , good evening)', depending on the time of day.
